text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

Schools should take a more active role in reducing and stopping the incidence of period shaming and period poverty. Schools are places that ought to be a place of comfort for its students, and should take more initiative to ensure the comfort and general well-being of its students - especially around issues that can be an awkward point of discussion for the students. Providing hygenic items, such as pads and tampons are critical to ensuring that goal, as by not doing so, they allow its female students to potentially experience negative outcomes such as bullying and or shaming due to their periods and their inability to acquire the items to remedy its symptoms.

While I have not personally experience period shaming or similar forms of ostracize, other women have expressed their experiences with me. Their experiences have been very impactful to my thoughts and perspectives, and I empathisize with the pain and discomfort they have gone through in school.

The idea that anyone should experience anything less than equal in school due to something out of their control is just illogical, and should definitely be stopped.

Schools should take a more active role in reducing and stopping the incidence of period shaming and period poverty. Schools are places that ought to be a place of comfort for its students, and should take more initiative to ensure the comfort and general well-being of its students - especially around issues that can be an awkward point of discussion for the students. Providing hygienic items, such as pads and tampons are critical to ensuring that goal, as by not doing so, they allow its female students to potentially experience negative outcomes such as bullying and or shaming due to their periods and their inability to acquire the items to remedy its symptoms. 

While I have not personally experience period shaming or similar forms of ostracize, other women have expressed their experiences with me. Their experiences have been very impactful to my thoughts and perspectives, and I empathize with the pain and discomfort they have gone through in school. The idea that anyone should be treated as than equal to others in school due to something out of their control is just illogical, and should definitely be stopped. Schools can do so regarding periods simply by providing free pads and tampons to students, just like it does with toilet paper, soap, and other hygienic items. These items should not be viewed as costs to the schools, but rather investments in ensuring the health and well-being of its students, who often have a hard time just talking about bodily functions due to societal taboos. Ensuring the health and well-being of its students will be of great benefit to their education, as , without good health, one can not function optimally.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

Schools should take a more active role in reducing and stopping the incidence of period shaming and period poverty. Schools are places that ought to be a place of comfort for its students, and should take more initiative to ensure the comfort and general well-being of its students - especially around issues that can be an awkward point of discussion for the students. Providing hygienic items, such as pads and tampons are critical to ensuring that goal, as by not doing so, they allow its female students to potentially experience negative outcomes such as bullying and or shaming due to their periods and their inability to acquire the items to remedy its symptoms. 

While I have not personally experience period shaming or similar forms of ostracize, other women have expressed their experiences with me. Their experiences have been very impactful to my thoughts and perspectives, and I empathize with the pain and discomfort they have gone through in school. The idea that anyone should be treated as than equal to others in school due to something out of their control is just illogical, and should definitely be stopped. Schools can do so regarding periods simply by providing free pads and tampons to students, just like it does with toilet paper, soap, and other hygienic items. These items should not be viewed as costs to the schools, but rather investments in ensuring the health and well-being of its students, who often have a hard time just talking about bodily functions due to societal taboos. Ensuring the health and well-being of its students will be of great benefit to their education, as, without both, one can not function optimally nor focus on their studies and learning.

Pads and tampons are quite similar to other hygenic items, especially bandages and plasters offered by the school. They both involve the stoppage of bleeding, and prevent people from staining their clothes, which is a positive outcome for them. The key thing to note is that pads and tampons still have a social stigma associated with them, thus greater care must be taken in their distribution.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

Schools should take a more active role in reducing and stopping the incidence of period shaming and period poverty. Schools are places that ought to be a place of comfort for its students, and should take more initiative to ensure the comfort and general well-being of its students - especially around issues that can be an awkward point of discussion for the students. Providing hygienic items, such as pads and tampons are critical to ensuring that goal, as by not doing so, they allow its female students to potentially experience negative outcomes such as bullying and or shaming due to their periods and their inability to acquire the items to remedy its symptoms. 

While I have not personally experience period shaming or similar forms of ostracize, other women have expressed their experiences with me. Their experiences have been very impactful to my thoughts and perspectives, and I empathize with the pain and discomfort they have gone through in school. The idea that anyone should be treated as than equal to others in school due to something out of their control is just illogical, and should definitely be stopped. Schools can do so regarding periods simply by providing free pads and tampons to students, just like it does with toilet paper, soap, and other hygienic items. These items should not be viewed as costs to the schools, but rather investments in ensuring the health and well-being of its students, who often have a hard time just talking about bodily functions due to societal taboos. Ensuring the health and well-being of its students will be of great benefit to their education, as, without both, one can not function optimally nor focus on their studies and learning.

Pads and tampons are quite similar to other hygenic items, especially bandages and plasters offered by the school. They both involve the stoppage of bleeding, and prevent people from staining their clothes, which is a positive outcome for them. The key thing to note is that pads and tampons still have a social stigma associated with them, thus greater care must be taken in their distribution. For example, schools should make sure that pads and tampons are distributed in areas where they are not visibly seen by students.

Privacy must be maintained for the female students, as it ensures their comfort and ease in asking for said items.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

Schools should take a more active role in reducing and stopping the incidence of period shaming and period poverty. Schools are places that ought to be a place of comfort for its students, and should take more initiative to ensure the comfort and general well-being of its students - especially around issues that can be an awkward point of discussion for the students. Providing hygienic items, such as pads and tampons are critical to ensuring that goal, as by not doing so, they allow its female students to potentially experience negative outcomes such as bullying and or shaming due to their periods and their inability to acquire the items to remedy its symptoms. 

While I have not personally experience period shaming or similar forms of ostracize, other women have expressed their experiences with me. Their experiences have been very impactful to my thoughts and perspectives, and I empathize with the pain and discomfort they have gone through in school. The idea that anyone should be treated as than equal to others in school due to something out of their control is just illogical, and should definitely be stopped. Schools can do so regarding periods simply by providing free pads and tampons to students, just like it does with toilet paper, soap, and other hygienic items. These items should not be viewed as costs to the schools, but rather investments in ensuring the health and well-being of its students, who often have a hard time just talking about bodily functions due to societal taboos. Ensuring the health and well-being of its students will be of great benefit to their education, as, without both, one can not function optimally nor focus on their studies and learning.

Pads and tampons are quite similar to other hygienic items, especially bandages and plasters offered by the school. They both involve the stoppage of bleeding, and prevent people from staining their clothes, which is a positive outcome for them. The key thing to note is that pads and tampons still have a social stigma associated with them, thus greater care must be taken in their distribution. For example, schools should make sure that pads and tampons are distributed in areas where they are not visibly seen by students, who may ridicule them afterwards for asking for such items. Privacy must be maintained for the female students, as it ensures their comfort and ease in asking for said items. Furthermore, schools should ensure that the female students’ access to such items are as easy as possible, as those with periods may already suffer from pain and would not want to go through difficult means to acquire them. Pads and tampons ought to be available in schools freely for students that require them, as they are beneficial to their comfort and education, but care must be taken to ensure that their distribution does not cause further ridicule or shaming from the other students.
